Margaret W. Ferguson observes: "Augustine is haunted by the parallel between the nature of language and the nature of man 'lost in our present sad dispersal.' His analysis of language as a sequence of parts is in many ways a forerunner of Derrida's discussions of language as a 'play of differences' that necessarily ruptures any concept of truth as a totality. Unlike modern theorists, how- ever, when faced with the contradictions between a philosophy of essence and a linguistics of difference, Augustine chooses to relinquish language rather than God" (p. 845).
